subject: RE: [junit] A test to verify that an event is generated
msgSnippet: Another excellent idea. Self-shunt is a simpler place to start. If you find that the TestCase needs to do more than be the event listener, then factor out the
messageBody:
Another excellent idea. Self-shunt is a simpler place to start. If you find that the TestCase needs to do more than be the event listener, then factor out the event listener into a separate SpyEventListener class.

Take care.

>So said Bernd on 4/18/2003 --------------------
>
>Kris,
>
>> Does anyone see any problems that might arise in this test?
>....
>> currentThread.sleep(5000);
>> fail("Timed out waiting for the event.");
>
>If the event is not generated it takes looooong for the test to fail.
>
>> Is there
>> a better/more prefered way to do this?
>
>as others said: avoid threading.
>
>
>and the listener may be the TestCase class itself
>(Is this called the "self shunt" pattern?):
>
>public MyTestCase extends TestCase implements MyEventListener{
>
> public void somethingHappened(MyEvent event)
> {
> // e.g. inc counter
> // e.g. add event to a list
> }
>....
>}
>
>Bernd
>
>
>> Here is the code/pseudocode of the test case I came up with:
>>
>> public void testEventGenerated()
>> {
>> MyClassThatFiresAnEvent myClass = new MyClassThatFiresAnEvent();
>>
>> final Thread currentThread = Thread.currentThread();
>>
>> myClass.addMyEventListener(new MyEventListener()
>> {
>> public void somethingHappened(MyEvent event)
>> {
>> currentThread.interrupt();
>> }
>> });
>>
>> Thread thread = new Thread()
>> {
>> public void run()
>> {
>> myClass.callMethodThatFiresTheEvent();
>> }
>> };
>> thread.start();
>>
>> try
>> {
>> currentThread.sleep(5000);
>> fail("Timed out waiting for the event.");
>> }
>> catch(InterruptedException ie)
>> {
>> System.out.println("Expect this exception");
>> }
>> }
>>
>> Thanks,
>> Kris
